[Statement 2]: Artificial nest sites for solitary bees can be provided using nest boxes made of cut hollow stems, tubes, or blocks of wood drilled with holes.
[Statement 3]: Artificial nest boxes for solitary bees have shown occupancy by many species of solitary bees in 29 out of 30 replicated trials across 10 countries.
[Statement 4]: The artificial nest boxes have also been occupied by endangered species on farmland in Germany.
[Statement 5]: Reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes are more productive than plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes due to reduced parasitism and mould.
[Statement 6]: Nest boxes can be provided for both solitary bees and bumblebees.
[Statement 7]: Solitary bee nest boxes show occupancy rates of 1-26% of available cavities.
[Statement 8]: Solitary bee nest boxes support between 4.6 and 33 bee species.
[Statement 9]: For solitary bees, the number of occupied nests can double over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site.
[Statement 10]: Bumblebee nest boxes show very low uptake rates of 2% or less.
[Statement 11]: Specific artificial nest sites for bumblebees include wooden or brick and tile boxes at the ground surface, underground tin, wooden or terracotta boxes, and boxes attached to trees.
[Statement 12]: Underground nest boxes for bumblebees buried 5-10 cm deep with 30-80 cm entrance pipes are most effective, showing 6-58% occupancy rates.
[Statement 13]: Wooden surface nest boxes for bumblebees show very low occupancy of 0-1.5% in recent UK trials.
[Statement 14]: Areas of rough grassland can be increased for bumblebee nesting.
[Statement 15]: Grassy field margins attract nest-searching queen bumblebees at higher densities than cropped field margins or other habitats.
[Statement 16]: Patches of bare ground can be created for ground-nesting bees.
[Statement 17]: Artificially exposed bare soil can be successfully colonized by ground-nesting solitary bees and wasps in the first or second year.
[Statement 18]: Excluding ants from solitary bee nesting sites is an additional protection measure.
[Statement 19]: The exclusion of ants from solitary bee nesting sites has been shown to increase offspring production in endemic Australian bees.
[Statement 20]: For effective use by European solitary bee species, nest boxes must be placed within 150-600 meters of foraging resources.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Floral resource interventions show different patterns of effectiveness at local patch versus landscape scales.
[Statement 2]: Fourteen trials in Europe and North America recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on perennial or annual sown flowering plants in agricultural environments.
[Statement 3]: Ten trials found substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, particularly bumblebees, on patches sown with phacelia.
[Statement 4]: The species richness of wild bees foraging on phacelia patches ranged from eight to 35 species in six trials.
[Statement 5]: Field margins sown with wild flowers consistently supported higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins across five replicated trials.
[Statement 6]: One trial in the Netherlands showed that bee numbers and species richness were not higher in farmland 50 to 1,500 meters away from planted flower patches.
[Statement 7]: At the landscape scale, one large replicated controlled trial showed that the average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of pollen and nectar agri-environment agreements in a 10 km grid square.
[Statement 8]: Studies of artificial nest sites found that four medium to large European species of solitary bee have a foraging range of 150 to 600 meters, indicating local-scale constraints on bee movement.
[Statement 9]: Landscape-scale evaluations found that two replicated trials in the UK showed bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri-environment schemes when compared at broad spatial scales.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do the impacts of planting floral resources for bees differ when implemented at a local patch scale versus a wider landscape scale?
